history.content:
281B deals with things like Rademacher complexity, and a large component is online learning and online convex optimization. It has almost nothing to do with CS 189. Take a look on the old course websites. Taking or not taking 189 /281A is irrelevant to "preparation" to 281B, as opposed to strong mathematical maturity. 

It's more useful for attacking the problems in which the incoming data has no good/tracttible model; i.e. a large part of the data in life is fairly unconstrained and can be assumed to be adversarial. This is how the exponential weights algorithm is derived, and is commonly used in dynamics in game theory, etc. A lot of industry algorithms (collaborative filtering, porfolio optimization, etc.)

You'll have a better experience if you think adversarially about things. 

Some terms you're going to have to learn the deep mathematics of: Rademacher complexity, mirror descent, bandits, VC-dimension, regret minimization.

children.subject: ^ so it means that you HAVE to take CS281A?
So many people tried to enroll in 281A this semester that the professor had to enforce prereqs very strictly. Probably the same thing will happen with 281B.

I'm not sure about that assumption because last year there were only 30 in the class. Depends if they'll change the subject matter for 281B, but if it's highly theoretical, I doubt it will be really full (as opposed to 281A's graphical models, which is more applied)
Also, people aren't taking 281a just because "graphical models are more applied." They're taking it because they just want to learn more ML.
According to Recht, they will be strictly enforcing the prereqs.

history.content:
how doable is CS281B if I have only taken CS189?

(the prereq mentions CS281A but not CS189)
history.subject: CS281B prereq
